timeline.headline: A day like today. 26-04
timeline.text: See what happened a day like today with data from Wikipedia and DBpedia!

date.headline: Battle of Las Salinas (War)
date.text:
The Battle of Las Salinas was a military conflict and decisive confrontation between the forces of Hernando and Gonzalo Pizarro against those of rival conquistador Diego de Almagro, on April 26, 1538, during the Conquest of Peru. Both camps claimed to represent the authority of the Spanish Crown; Pizarro's forces controlled the province of Nueva Castilla, and those of Almagro, Nueva Toledo.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Battles of Komárom (War)
date.text:
Three Battles of Komárom were fought in the Hungarian Revolution of 1848 between the Hungarian and Austrian armies at the Castle of Komárom. The Austrian legions were attacking Komárom from December 1848. Under the command of János Damjanich and György Klapka Hungarian troops arrived to liberate the city. Four days later the Hungarian legions were successful and beat Austrians.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Action of 26 April 1797 (War)
date.text:
The Action of 26 April 1797 was a minor naval engagement during the French Revolutionary Wars in which a Spanish convoy of two frigates was trapped and defeated off the Spanish town of Conil de la Frontera by British ships of the Cadiz blockade.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Battle of Sand Butte (War)
date.text:
The Battle of Sand Butte or the Thomas Massacre was a clash between the Modoc Indians and the United States 12th Infantry Regiment in the Modoc War. A small force of US troops were ambushed and wiped out by Modoc warriors led by Scarface Charley.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Hispano-Moroccan War (1859–1860) (War)
date.text:
The Hispano-Moroccan War, also known as the Spanish–Moroccan War, the First Moroccan War, the Tetuán War, or, in Spain, as the African War (Spanish: La Guerra de África), was fought from Spain's declaration of war on Morocco on 22 October 1859 until the Treaty of Wad-Ras on 26 April 1860. It began with a conflict over the borders of the Spanish city of Ceuta and was fought in northern Morocco. Morocco sued for peace after the Spanish victory at the Battle of Tetuán.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Battle of Mogadishu (March–April 2007) (War)
date.text:
The Battle of Mogadishu began on 21 March 2007 in the Shirkole area of Mogadishu between Somali Transitional Federal Government forces and Ethiopian troops, and Islamist insurgents.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Expedition 7 (Space mission)
date.text:
Expedition 7 was the seventh expedition to the International Space Station.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Dolores Cassinelli (Death)
date.text:
Dolores Cassinelli (July 4, 1888– April 26, 1984) was an American film actress. She appeared in 69 films between 1911 and 1925. She is interred at Holy Redeemer Cemetery in South Plainfield, New Jersey.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Samuel Zoll (Death)
date.text:
Samuel Edward Zoll (June 20, 1934 – April 26, 2011) was an American lawyer, judge and politician. He began his career as a high school teacher then became a lawyer, politician, then a judge. Later in life he was named to be Chief Justice of the District Courts in Massachusetts.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Jill Dando (Death)
date.text:
Jill Wendy Dando (9 November 1961 – 26 April 1999) was an English journalist, television presenter and newsreader who worked for the BBC for 14 years. She was murdered by gunshot outside her home in Fulham, West London; her killer has never been identified.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Pope Stephen II (Death)
date.text:
In sources prior to the 1960s, this Pope is sometimes called Stephen III and Pope-elect Stephen is sometimes called Stephen II. See Pope-elect Stephen for detailed explanations.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Catherine of Bohemia (Death)
date.text:
Catherine of Bohemia (19 August 1342 – 26 April 1395) was an Electress of Brandenburg, the second daughter of Emperor Charles IV and Blanche of Valois.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Magnus Gabriel De la Gardie (Death)
date.text:
Count Magnus Gabriel De la Gardie (15 October 1622 – 26 April 1686) was a Swedish statesman and military man. He became a member of the Swedish Privy Council in 1647 and came to be the holder of three of the five offices counted as the Great Officers of the Realm, namely Lord High Treasurer, Lord High Chancellor and Lord High Steward. He also served as Governor-General in the Swedish dominion of Livonia.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: John Somers, 1st Baron Somers (Death)
date.text:
John Somers, 1st Baron Somers, PC, FRS (4 March 1651 – 26 April 1716) was an English Whig jurist and statesman. Somers first came to national attention in the trial of the Seven Bishops where he was on the their defence counsel. He published tracts on political topics such as the succession to the crown, where he elaborated his Whig principles in support of the Exclusionists. He played a leading part in shaping the Revolution settlement.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Samuel Cranston (Death)
date.text:
Samuel Cranston (1659–1727) was a governor of the Colony of Rhode Island and Providence Plantations during the first quarter of the 18th century. He held office from 1698 to 1727, being elected to office 30 times (twice in 1698), and served as governor longer than any other individual in the history of both the colony and the state of Rhode Island. The son of former Rhode Island Governor John Cranston, he was born in Newport and lived there his entire life.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Muhammad Shah (Death)
date.text:
Shahanshah Nasir-ud-Din Muhammad Shah, Abu Al-Fatah Nasir-ud-Din Roshan Akhtar Muhammad Shah (محمد شاه) (1748 – 1702) also known as Roshan Akhtar, was the Mughal emperor between 1719 and 1748. He was son of Khujista Akhtar, the fourth son of Bahadur Shah I. Ascending the throne at 17 with the help of the Sayyid Brothers, he later got rid of them with the help of Asaf Jah I.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Baxter E. Perry (Death)
date.text:
Baxter E. Perry (April 26, 1826 –) was a Massachusetts attorney and politician. Perry served in the Massachusetts House of Representatives and as the second Mayor of Medford, Massachusetts.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Lucia Migliaccio (Death)
date.text:
Lucia Migliaccio, Duchess of Floridia (19 July 1770, Syracuse, Sicily - 26 April 1826, Naples) was the second wife of Ferdinand I of the Two Sicilies. Their marriage was morganatic and Lucia was never a Queen consort.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Johan Lundbye (Death)
date.text:
Johan Thomas Lundbye (1 September 1818 - 25 April 1848) was a promising young Danish painter and graphic artist, known for his animal and landscape paintings who died at the age of 29. He was artistically inspired by Niels Laurits Høyen's call to develop a Danish nationalistic art by exploring as motif the characteristic landscapes, the historical buildings and monuments, and the simple, rural people of Denmark. He became one of his generation’s national romantic painters, along with P.C.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Peter Estenberg (Death)
date.text:
Peter Estenberg (also known as Peter von Estenberg and Petrus Estenberg) lived in the late 17th - early 18th century and was a member of the Swedish nobility of the house of Estenberg, a noted scholar, and an ambassador to Poland. His family Coat of Arms is displayed in the Riddarhuset in Stockholm. In the early 18th century, Peter Estenberg became an advisor to Poland's King Stanislaw.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Maria Zhukova (Death)
date.text:
Maria Semyonovna Zhukova (Russian: Мари́я Семёновна Жу́кова, 1805 – April 26, 1855) was a Russian writer.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Hotta Masayoshi (Death)
date.text:
Hotta Masayoshi was a Japanese daimyo in the Edo period; and he was a prominent figure in the Tokugawa shogunate.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Archduchess Auguste Ferdinande of Austria (Death)
date.text:
Archduchess Auguste Ferdinande of Austria, Princess of Bavaria (1 April 1825, Florence – 26 April 1864, Munich) was the daughter of Leopold II, Grand Duke of Tuscany, and his first wife Maria Anna of Saxony, and the wife of Luitpold, Prince Regent of Bavaria.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: John Wilkes Booth (Death)
date.text:
John Wilkes Booth (May 10, 1838 – April 26, 1865) was a famous American stage actor who assassinated President Abraham Lincoln at Ford's Theatre, in Washington, D.C. , on April 14, 1865. Booth was a member of the prominent 19th century Booth theatrical family from Maryland and, by the 1860s, was a well-known actor. He was also a Confederate sympathizer vehement in his denunciation of the Lincoln Administration and outraged by the South's defeat in the American Civil War.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Hermann Goldschmidt (Death)
date.text:
Hermann Mayer Salomon Goldschmidt (June 17, 1802 – April 26, 1866) was a German-French astronomer and painter who spent much of his life in France. He started out as a painter, but after attending a lecture by the famous French astronomer Urbain Le Verrier turned to astronomy. His discovery of the asteroid Lutetia in 1852 was followed by further findings and by 1861 Goldschmidt had discovered 14 asteroids.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Edmund Nelson (clergyman) (Death)
date.text:
Reverend Edmund Nelson (19 March 1722 – 26 April 1802) was an Anglican clergyman during the eighteenth century, most famous as the father of Horatio Nelson.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville (Death)
date.text:
Édouard-Léon Scott de Martinville (25 April 1817 – 26 April 1879) was a French printer and bookseller who lived in Paris. He invented the earliest known sound recording device, the phonautograph, which was patented in France on 25 March 1857.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: John G. Palfrey (Death)
date.text:
John Gorham Palfrey (May 2, 1796 – April 26, 1881) was an American clergyman and historian who served as a U.S. Representative from Massachusetts. A Unitarian minister, he played a leading role in the early history of Harvard Divinity School, and he later became involved in politics as a State Representative and U.S. Congressman.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Joseph Lemuel Chester (Death)
date.text:
Joseph Lemuel Chester (1821–1882) was an American genealogist.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Napoleon Orda (Death)
date.text:
Napoleon Orda (February 11, 1807 – April 26, 1883) was a Polish-Lithuanian musician, pianist, composer and artist. Napoleon Orda was born in the village of Varacevičy in the Pinsk district of Minsk guberniya in his father's manor. His father Michał Orda was an impoverished noble and the marshal of the powiat of Kobryn. After finishing Svislach gymnasium in 1823, he started mathematical studies at the Vilnius University.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Stephen Lindsey (Death)
date.text:
Stephen Decatur Lindsey (March 3, 1828 – April 26, 1884) was a nineteenth-century politician and lawyer from Maine. Born in Norridgewock, Maine, Lindsey attended the common schools as a child and attended Broomfield Academy. He studied law and was admitted to the bar in Norridgewock in 1853. He was a member of the Maine House of Representatives in 1856, a clerk of the judicial courts of Somerset County, Maine from 1857 to 1860, and a delegate to the Republican National Convention in 1860.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Alice Ayres (Death)
date.text:
Alice Ayres (12 September 1859 – 26 April 1885) was an English nursemaid honoured for her bravery in rescuing the children in her care from a house fire. Ayres was a household assistant and nursemaid to the family of her brother-in-law and sister, Henry and Mary Ann Chandler. The Chandlers owned an oil and paint shop in Union Street, Southwark, then just south of London, and Ayres lived with the family above the shop.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Henry Kater (Death)
date.text:
Henry Kater (16 April 1777 – 26 April 1835) was an English physicist of German descent.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: George Watson (Royal Navy officer) (Death)
date.text:
Vice Admiral Sir George Willes Watson KCB (5 April 1827 – 26 April 1897) was a Royal Navy officer who went on to be Commander-in-Chief, North America and West Indies Station.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Battle of Trekkopjes (War)
date.text:
The Battle of Trekkopjes on April 26, 1915 was a German assault on the South African held town of Trekkopjes during the South-West Africa Campaign of World War I. The South African Major Skinner had been ordered to defend Trekkopjes, and came into contact with a German column advancing on that town. Skinner withdrew back into Trekkopjes and dug in his forces. The German attack was repulsed with the help of armoured cars, leaving the South Africans victorious.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Algiers putsch of 1961 (War)
date.text:
The Algiers putsch (French: Putsch d'Alger or Coup d'État d'Alger), also known as the Generals' putsch (Putsch des Généraux), was a failed coup d'état to overthrow French President Charles de Gaulle (70) and establish an anti-communist military junta.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Leo Arnaud (Death)
date.text:
Leo Arnaud or Léo Arnaud was a French-American composer of film scores, best known for Bugler's Dream, which is used as the theme by television networks presenting the Olympic Games in the United States. The composer studied composition at conservatories in Lyon and Paris with Maurice Ravel and Vincent d'Indy. After playing as a jazz trombonist in France using the name Leo Vauchant and arranging for the Jack Hylton band in England from 1928 to 1930, he immigrated to the United States in 1931.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Josiah Quincy II (Death)
date.text:
Josiah Quincy, Jr. , was an American lawyer and patriot. He was a principal spokesman for the Sons of Liberty in Boston prior to the Revolution and was John Adams' co-counsel during the trials of Captain Thomas Preston and the soldiers involved in the Boston Massacre.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Zerah Colburn (locomotive designer) (Death)
date.text:
Zerah Colburn (January 13, 1832 – April 26, 1870) was an American engineer specialising in steam locomotive design, technical journalist and publisher.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Pedro Alcántara Herrán (Death)
date.text:
Pedro Alcántara Herrán Martínez de Zaldúa was a Colombian general and statesman who served as President of the Republic of the New Granada between 1841 and 1845. As a general he served in the wars of independence of the New Granada and of Peru.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Edward Hale (politician) (Death)
date.text:
Edward Hale (December 6, 1800 – April 26, 1875) was a Quebec businessman and political figure. He was born in Quebec City in 1800, the son of John Hale; his mother was the sister of Lord William Pitt Amherst. Hale was educated in England and returned to Lower Canada in 1820, where he was named secretary to the auditor general for the province. From 1823 to 1828, he was secretary to his uncle, Lord Amherst, in India.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Ludwig Uhland (Birth)
date.text:
Johann Ludwig Uhland (26 April 1787 – 13 November 1862), was a German poet, philologist and literary historian.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Grigory Danilevsky (Birth)
date.text:
Grigory Petrovich Danilevsky (Russian: Григо́рий Петро́вич Даниле́вский, Ukrainian: Григорій Петрович Данилевський; April 26  1829 - December 18  1890) was a Russian historical novelist.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Ida Hawley (Birth)
date.text:
Ida Hawley (1876–1908) was a Canadian musical comedy actress and soprano singer. Ida Hawley 41 kbBorn 26 April 1876Belleville, Ontario, CanadaDied 9 December 1908New York City, New YorkOccupation Musical Comedy Actress

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Vicente Aleixandre (Birth)
date.text:
Vicente Pío Marcelino Cirilo Aleixandre y Merlo (April 26, 1898 – December 14, 1984) was a Spanish poet who was born in Seville. Aleixandre was a Nobel Prize laureate for Literature in 1977. He was part of the Generation of '27. He died in Madrid in 1984. Aleixandre's early poetry, which he wrote mostly in free verse, is highly surrealistic. It also praises the beauty of nature by using symbols that represent the earth and the sea. Many of Aleixandre's early poems are filled with sadness.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Meša Selimović (Birth)
date.text:
Mehmed "Meša" Selimović (Serbian Cyrillic: Мехмед Селимовић "Меша"; 26 April 1910 - 11 July 1982) was a Bosnian writer. His novel Death and the Dervish is one of the most important literary works in post-WWII Yugoslavia. Some of the main themes in his works are the relations between individuality and authority, life and death, and other existential problems. His ethnicity and nationality as well as how he considered himself in these terms is a matter of some dispute.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Morris West (Birth)
date.text:
Morris Langlo West AO (26 April 1916 – 9 October 1999) was an Australian novelist and playwright, best known for his novels The Devil's Advocate (1959), The Shoes of the Fisherman (1963), and The Clowns of God (1981). His books were published in 27 languages and sold more than 60 million copies worldwide. Each new book he wrote after he became an established writer sold more than 1 million copies.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Kurumizawa Koshi (Birth)
date.text:
Kurumizawa Koshi was the pen-name of a writer in Showa period Japan. His real name was Shimizu Masatarō.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Mark Burgess (children's author) (Birth)
date.text:
Mark Burgess (born 26 April 1957; pen name Simon Goswell for two books) is best known as an English author and illustrator of children's literature. He has illustrated books by Tony Bradman and Martin Waddell. Among his most recent assignments, he illustrated Return to the Hundred Acre Wood, the authorized sequel of Winnie-the-Pooh. Burgess also designs greeting cards and is a computer programmer.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Tukufu Zuberi (Birth)
date.text:
Tukufu Zuberi (born April 26, 1959) is an American sociologist, filmmaker, social critic, educator, and writer. He is the Lasry Family Professor of Race Relations, and Professor and Chair of the Sociology Department at the University of Pennsylvania. Zuberi has appeared in several documentaries on Africa and the African diaspora, including Liberia: America's Stepchild (2002), and 500 Years Later (2005). He is also one of the hosts of the PBS program History Detectives.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Lisa Unger (Birth)
date.text:
Lisa Unger (born April 26, 1970 in New Haven, Connecticut) is an American author of contemporary fiction.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: A. E. van Vogt (Birth)
date.text:
Alfred Elton van Vogt (April 26, 1912 – January 26, 2000) was a Canadian-born science fiction author regarded as one of the most popular and complex science fiction writers of the mid-twentieth century: the "Golden Age" of the genre.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: H. L. Gold (Birth)
date.text:
Horace Leonard Gold (April 26, 1914, Montreal, Canada - February 21, 1996, Laguna Hills, California, U.S.A. ) was a science fiction writer and editor. Born in Canada, Gold moved to the United States at the age of two. He was most noted for bringing an innovative and fresh approach to science fiction while he was the editor of Galaxy Science Fiction, and also wrote briefly for DC Comics.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Bernard Malamud (Birth)
date.text:
Bernard Malamud (April 26, 1914 – March 18, 1986) was an American author of novels and short stories. Along with Saul Bellow and Philip Roth, he was one of the great American Jewish authors of the 20th century. His baseball novel, The Natural, was adapted into a 1984 film starring Robert Redford. His 1966 novel The Fixer, about antisemitism in Tsarist Russia, won both the National Book Award and the Pulitzer Prize.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Dragotin Kette (Death)
date.text:
Dragotin Kette (19 January 1876 - 26 April 1899) was a Slovene Impressionist and Neo-Romantic poet. Together with Josip Murn, Ivan Cankar and Oton Župančič, he is considered as the beginner of modernism in Slovene literature.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Bjørnstjerne Bjørnson (Death)
date.text:
Bjørnstjerne Martinius Bjørnson (8 December 1832 – 26 April 1910) was a Norwegian writer and the 1903 Nobel Prize in Literature laureate. Bjørnson is considered as one of The Four Greats (De Fire Store) Norwegian writers; the others being Henrik Ibsen, Jonas Lie, and Alexander Kielland. Bjørnson is celebrated for his lyrics to the Norwegian National Anthem, "Ja, vi elsker dette landet".

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Mário de Sá-Carneiro (Death)
date.text:
Mário de Sá-Carneiro (Lisbon, May 19, 1890 — Paris, April 26, 1916) was a Portuguese poet and writer. He is one of the most well known of the "Geração D'Orpheu".

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: E. J. Pratt (Death)
date.text:
Edwin John Dove Pratt, FRSC (February 4, 1882 – April 26, 1964), who published as E. J. Pratt, was "the leading Canadian poet of his time. " He was a Canadian poet originally from Newfoundland who lived most of his life in Toronto, Ontario. A three-time winner of the country's Governor General's Award for poetry, he has been called "the foremost Canadian poet of the first half of the century."

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Armstrong Sperry (Death)
date.text:
Armstrong Wells Sperry (November 7, 1897–April 26, 1976) was an American writer and illustrator of children's literature. His books include historical fiction and biography, often set on sailing ships, and stories of boys from Polynesia, Asia and indigenous American cultures. He is best known for his 1941 Newbery Medal-winning book Call It Courage.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Luis Rosales (Death)
date.text:
Luis Rosales Camacho (Granada, May 31 of 1910 – Madrid, April 26 of 1992) was a Spanish poet and essay writer member of the Generation of '36. Member of the Hispanic Society of America and the Royal Spanish Academy since 1962. Rosales obtained the Miguel de Cervantes Prize in 1982 for his literary work.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: David Lavender (Death)
date.text:
David Sievert Lavender (February 4, 1910 – April 26, 2003) was an American historian and writer of the Western United States. He published more than 40 books, including two novels, several children's books, and a memoir. Unlike his two prominent contemporaries, Bernard DeVoto and Wallace Stegner, Lavender was not an academic.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Hubert Selby, Jr. (Death)
date.text:
Hubert "Cubby" Selby, Jr. (July 23, 1928 – April 26, 2004) was a 20th century American writer. His best-known novels are Last Exit to Brooklyn (1964) and Requiem for a Dream (1978). Both novels were later adapted into films within his lifetime.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Augusto Roa Bastos (Death)
date.text:
Augusto Roa Bastos, (June 13, 1917 – April 26, 2005) was a noted Paraguayan novelist and short story writer, and one of the most important Latin American writers of the 20th century. As a teenager he fought in the Chaco War between Paraguay and Bolivia, and he later worked as a journalist, screenwriter and professor. He is best known for his complex novel Yo el Supremo and for his reception of the Premio Miguel de Cervantes in 1989, Spanish literature's most prestigious prize.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Richard Cornuelle (Death)
date.text:
Richard Charles Cornuelle (April 10, 1927 – April 26, 2011) was an early libertarian who gained national prominence after turning against free-market extremism.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Kang Kyeong-ae (Death)
date.text:
Kang Gyeong-ae (20 April 1907 - 26 April 1944) was a Korean writer and novelists, Feminists movements. a penname was Gama.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Count Basie (Death)
date.text:
William "Count" Basie (August 21, 1904 – April 26, 1984) was an American jazz pianist, organist, bandleader, and composer. His mother first taught him piano and he started performing in his teens. Dropping out of school, he learned to operate lights for vaudeville and improvised to accompany silent films at a local theater in his town of Red Bank, New Jersey. By 16, he increasingly played jazz piano at parties, resorts and other venues.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Adrian Borland (Death)
date.text:
Adrian Borland (6 December 1957 – 26 April 1999) was an English singer, songwriter, guitarist and record producer, best known as the lead singer of post-punk band The Sound (1979–87). Following a substantial solo career spanning five albums he succumbed to the symptoms of schizoid-affective disorder and committed suicide in April 1999.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Phoebe Snow (Death)
date.text:
Phoebe Snow (born Phoebe Ann Laub; July 17, 1950 – April 26, 2011) was an American singer, songwriter, and guitarist, best known for her chart-topping 1975 hit "Poetry Man". She was described by The New York Times as a "contralto grounded in a bluesy growl and capable of sweeping over four octaves."

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Ma Rainey (Birth)
date.text:
Ma Rainey (April 26, 1886 – December 22, 1939) was one of the earliest known American professional blues singers and one of the first generation of such singers to record. She was billed as The Mother of the Blues. She began performing at the age of 12 or 14, and recorded under the name Ma Rainey after she and Will Rainey were married in 1904. They toured with F.S. Wolcott’s Rabbit Foot Minstrels and later formed their own group called Rainey and Rainey, Assassinators of the Blues.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Giorgio Moroder (Birth)
date.text:
Hansjörg "Giorgio" Moroder, named on record sleeves often only Giorgio is an Italian record producer, songwriter and performer based in Los Angeles. When in Munich in the 1970s, he started his own record label called Oasis Records, which several years later became a subdivision of Casablanca Records.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Marko Savić (Birth)
date.text:
Marko Savić (born 26 April 1941) is a Serbian pianist and university professor.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: L. Shankar (Birth)
date.text:
Lakshminarayanan Shankar, also known as L. Shankar and Shenkar, is an Indian-born American violinist, singer and composer.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Dave Pomeroy (Birth)
date.text:
Dave Pomeroy (born April 26, 1956) is a United States musician, known as a Nashville vocalist, songwriter, and producer (Earwave Productions), but is best known as a bassist. He has played electric and acoustic bass in the studio for many recording artists in addition to his solo and concert work. He also has written numerous articles and columns for Bass Player magazine, and has contributed as a writer to a number of books about the music business.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Roger Taylor (Duran Duran drummer) (Birth)
date.text:
Roger Andrew Taylor (born 26 April 1960) is an English double grammy award winning musician who is best known as the drummer of British rock band Duran Duran from their inception until 1985, and again from 2001 onwards, the band selling in excess of 80 million records worldwide in the process.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Bobby Rydell (Birth)
date.text:
Bobby Rydell (born Robert Louis Ridarelli, 26 April 1942, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania) is an American professional singer, mainly of rock and roll music. In the early 1960s he was considered a "teen idol". According to Allmusic music journalist Kim Summers, Rydell, whose interest in show business began at the age of four years, "is one of the most sought-after nightclub and concert acts in the US.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Cormega (Birth)
date.text:
Corey McKay (born April 26, 1970), better known by his stage name Cormega, is an African-American rapper best known for his narratives about inner-city life, having been born in Queensbridge, Queens. McKay is notable for consistently producing as an independent artist, refusing to go mainstream.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Jay DeMarcus (Birth)
date.text:
Jay DeMarcus (born Stanley Wayne DeMarcus, Jr. ; April 26, 1971) is an American bass guitarist, harmony vocalist, pianist, record producer and songwriter, who is a member of the country trio Rascal Flatts.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Giorgia Todrani (Birth)
date.text:
Giorgia Todrani, best known as Giorgia (born April 26, 1971) is an Italian female singer and song-writer, known for her soulful voice, which is aided by a wide vocal range, high belting register and great vocal abilities. She is one of the most iconic and famous Italian singers. She has released ten studio albums, which all enjoyed good commercial success in Italy.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Adrian Lambert (Birth)
date.text:
Adrian Lambert (born 26 April 1972 in Brighton) is an English bassist and songwriter who currently plays for thrash metal band Biomechanical and progressive rock band Son of Science. Lambert also played bass in power metal band DragonForce from 2002 - 2006. Lambert is currently touring with Biomechanical to promote the band's new album Cannibalised. Lambert has also joined a new as yet unnamed band led by former Testament/Nevermore guitarist Steve Smyth.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Sam Totman (Birth)
date.text:
Ian Samuel "Sam" Totman (born 26 April 1980 in London, UK) is a guitarist and main songwriter for the power metal band DragonForce. Totman was born in England, but moved to New Zealand at an early age. He began playing classical guitar at the age of nine, receiving formal training for many years. He was part of the blackened power metal band Demoniac, which also featured his future DragonForce bandmate Herman Li.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Piotta (musician) (Birth)
date.text:
Piotta is a stage name of Tommaso Zanello (born 26 April 1974 in Rome, Italy), an Italian rapper. Piotta, which in Roman slang means "100 liras", became famous with his song "Supercafone" which describes the Coatto (suburban unpolite, politically incorrect peasant). Piotta's single "La Mossa del giaguaro" hit #15 on the Italian charts in 2000. Now considered a "veteran" of Italian hip hop, Piotta set up a record label, La grande onda, with a focus on emerging Italian musicians.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Thomas Reid (Birth)
date.text:
The Reverend Thomas Reid FRSE, was a religiously trained Scottish philosopher, and a contemporary of David Hume, was the founder of the Scottish School of Common Sense, and played an integral role in the Scottish Enlightenment. The early part of his life was spent in Aberdeen, Scotland, where he created the 'Wise Club' (a literary-philosophical association) and graduated from the University of Aberdeen.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: David Hume (Birth)
date.text:
David Hume (7 May  1711 – 25 August 1776) was a Scottish philosopher, historian, economist, and essayist, known especially for his philosophical empiricism and scepticism. He was one of the most important figures in the history of Western philosophy and the Scottish Enlightenment. Hume is often grouped with John Locke, George Berkeley, and a handful of others as a British Empiricist.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Hermann Graf Keyserling (Death)
date.text:
Hermann Alexander Graf Keyserling (July 20, 1880–April 26, 1946) was a wealthy philosopher from the aristocratic Baltic German Keyserlingk family. He married Maria Goedela von Bismarck-Schönhausen, granddaughter of Otto von Bismarck. His son Arnold Keyserling was a renowned philosopher as well.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Eugène Delacroix (Birth)
date.text:
Ferdinand Victor Eugène Delacroix (26 April 1798 – 13 August 1863) was a French Romantic artist regarded from the outset of his career as the leader of the French Romantic school. Delacroix's use of expressive brushstrokes and his study of the optical effects of colour profoundly shaped the work of the Impressionists, while his passion for the exotic inspired the artists of the Symbolist movement.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Akseli Gallen-Kallela (Birth)
date.text:
Akseli Gallen-Kallela (26 April 1865, Pori – 7 March 1931) was a Finnish painter who is best known for his illustrations of the Kalevala, the Finnish national epic (illustration, below). His work was considered very important for the Finnish national identity. He changed his name from Gallen to Gallen-Kallela in 1907.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Julius Zeyer (Birth)
date.text:
Julius Zeyer (April 26, 1841 – January 29, 1901) was a Czech prose writer, poet, and playwright.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Vernon Simeon Plemion Grant (Birth)
date.text:
Vernon Simeon Plemion Grant (1902–1990) was an American illustrator known for his whimsical gnome characters and fairy tale drawings. Over seven decades, Grant created hundreds of illustrations for advertising and major magazines, including Judge and Ladies' Home Journal. He is best known as creator of Kellogg’s Rice Krispies cereal characters Snap! Crackle! and Pop!

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Edward Laning (Birth)
date.text:
Edward Laning was an American painter.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Ruan Lingyu (Birth)
date.text:
Ruan Lingyu, born Ruan Fenggen, was a Chinese silent film actress. One of the most prominent Chinese film stars of the 1930s, her death at the age of 24 led her to become an icon of Chinese cinema.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Don Raffell (Birth)
date.text:
Don Raffell (b. Apr 26, 1919, Washington D.C. - d. Mar 24, 2003, Sherman Oaks, California) was an American saxophonist, woodwind doubler, studio musician and educator. Raffell recorded on hundreds of records, movies, and T. V shows dating from the 1940s all the way through the 1990s. His career as a studio musician was long and stylistically diverse having started in the big band era and playing all the way up through rock n' roll and other modern pop era acts.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Édouard Cortès (Birth)
date.text:
Édouard Leon Cortès (1882–1969) was a French post-impressionist artist of French and Spanish ancestry. He is known as "Le Poete Parisien de la Peinture" or "the Parisian Poet of Painting" because of his diverse Paris cityscapes in a variety of weather and night settings.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Vera Nazina (Birth)
date.text:
Vera Ivanovna Nazina (Russian: Ве́ра Ива́новна На́зина; April 26, 1931, Leningrad, USSR) - soviet Russian painter, Graphic artist, living and working in Saint Petersburg, a member of the Saint Petersburg Union of Artists (before 1992 - Leningrad branch of Union of Artists of Russian Federation), regarded by one art historian as one of representatives of the Leningrad school of painting.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Florijan Mićković (Birth)
date.text:
Florijan Mićković (born 1935) is a Bosnia and Herzegovina sculptor living and working in Mostar and Medjugorje (Bijakovići).

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Henry de Montherlant (Birth)
date.text:
Henry Marie Joseph Frédéric Expedite Millon de Montherlant (20 April 1895 – 21 September 1972) was a French essayist, novelist, and dramatist. He was a notorious Nazi collaborator. He was elected to the Académie Française in 1960.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Kerry Gammill (Birth)
date.text:
Kerry Gammill (b. April 26, 1954) is an American artist who has worked in the fields of comic books, special effects, storyboards, and character designs.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Jay Oliver (Birth)
date.text:
Jay Oliver is an American jazz musician, composer, record producer, programmer & engineer; residing in Los Angeles. He began his professional music career at the age of 19 as the youngest member of Maynard Ferguson’s band. His later credits include: Sheryl Crow, The Eagles, Jimmy Buffett, Wynona Judd, Glenn Frey, Peabo Bryson, Chick Corea, Dave Weckl, Russ Kunkel, Jay Graydon, Aomusic, Celine Dion, Bonnie Raitt, Lili Haydn, Michael Brecker and many others.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: John Corabi (Birth)
date.text:
John Corabi (born on April 26, 1959 in Philadelphia, Pennsylvania) is a heavy metal singer and guitarist who has worked with such bands as Angora, The Scream, Mötley Crüe, Union and ESP, Ratt (as a guitarist), Twenty 4 Seven (with his then Ratt bandmate Bobby Blotzer), Zen Lunatic, Brides of Destruction, and Angel City Outlaws (with his then Ratt bandmates Robbie Crane and Bobby Blotzer, and former Ratt guitarist Keri Kelli, who he replaced in Ratt).

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Thanassis Papakonstantinou (Birth)
date.text:
Athanasios (Thanasis) Papakonstantinou (born April 26, 1959, at Tyrnavos) is a Greek singer-songwriter.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: William Tester (Birth)
date.text:
William Tester (born April 26, 1960, in Charleston, South Carolina) is an American short story writer and novelist. He was raised on a cattle ranch in Florida and is a graduate of Columbia University (B.A. , 1984) and Syracuse University (M.F.A. , 1995). He published the novel Darling in 1991 and the story collection Head in 2000. He is the recipient of a National Endowment for the Arts Fellowship and The Mary McCarthy Prize.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Gyula Kosice (Birth)
date.text:
Gyula Kosice, born Fernando Fallik (April 26, 1924) in Košice (Slovakia) is a naturalized Argentine sculptor, plastic artist, theoretician and poet, one of the most important figures in kinetic and luminal art and luminance vanguard. He used his natal city name as artist name. He was one of the precursors of abstract and non-figurative art in Latin America. He used, for the first time in international art scene, water and neon gas as part of an artwork.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Sabina Shikhlinskaya (Birth)
date.text:
Sabina Shikhlinskaya; born April 26, 1962, Baku is an Azerbaijani artist and independent curator. She works in painting, video and photography. Being well known with her early modernistic paintings, in the 90s she transitioned to contemporary art. She is one of the pioneers of conceptual art in Azerbaijan. Shikhlinskaya's work explores actual problems of relationship between individual and society. In the art projects curated by Sabina Shikhlinskaya, the social subject is also of high priority.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: John Paul Leon (Birth)
date.text:
John Paul Leon (born April 26, 1972 in New York City) is an American comic book artist, known for his work on the Milestone Comics series Static, and the Marvel Comics limited series Earth X.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Joey Jordison (Birth)
date.text:
Joey Jordison (born Nathan Jonas Jordison April 26, 1975 in Des Moines, Iowa), is an American musician, songwriter, and record producer, best known for his work as the drummer for the nu metal band Slipknot. He grew up in Waukee, Iowa with his parents and two sisters, and was given his first drum kit at the age of 8. He performed in several bands until joining in the summer of 1995 the group The Pale Ones, which would later change their name to Slipknot.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Nerina Pallot (Birth)
date.text:
Nerina Pallot (born Nerina Natasha Georgina Pallot, 26 April 1975, London) is a platinum selling, BRIT Award and Ivor Novello Award nominated British singer and songwriter. Although born in London, Pallot was brought up in Jersey to a half-French father and mother from Allahabad, India.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Emily Mitchell (Birth)
date.text:
Emily Mitchell is an Anglo-American novelist. Her first novel, "The Last Summer of the World", was published by WW Norton in 2007. It concerns the photographer Edward Steichen in the context of World War I and was a finalist for the 2008 Young Lions Award for fiction. Her writing has appeared in The Indiana Review, AGNI, The Nation, and The Utne Reader.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Brisa Roché (Birth)
date.text:
Brisa Roché (born La Brisa Day Roché, April 26, 1976 in Arcata, California) is an American singer-songwriter, currently residing in France. She sings in English and French.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Daniel Rostén (Birth)
date.text:
Daniel Rostén is a Swedish black metal vocalist, guitarist, and bassist, known as the frontman for Funeral Mist and singer/guitarist of Triumphator under the stage name Arioch, and for having been the vocalist for renowned Swedish black metal band Marduk since 2004 under the stage name Mortuus He also runs a graphic design company called Holy Poison Design.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Saša Matić (Birth)
date.text:
Aleksandar "Saša" Matić is a Bosnian Serb folk singer, very popular in former Yugoslavia. He has a twin brother, Dejan Matić, who is also a popular singer. Both of them were born completely blind.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Janne Wirman (Birth)
date.text:
Janne Viljami Wirman (born 26 April 1979) is a Finnish musician; he is the keyboardist for the bands Children of Bodom and Warmen.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Ariane Moffatt (Birth)
date.text:
Ariane Moffatt (born 26 April 1979) is a Québécoise singer-songwriter. Known for working across multiple musical genres, Moffatt's music combines elements of electronica, jazz, folk, and pop. A francophone, she is bilingual and has recorded tracks in both French and English.

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...

date.headline: Jeffreys Lewis (Death)
date.text:
Jeffreys Lewis (abt. 1852–1926) was a British-born American actress whose career lasted long after her popularity as a leading lady had faded. Mary Jeffreys Lewis File:Jeffreys-Lewis001. JPGNYPL Digital CollectionBorn Template:Safesubst:25 October 1852(1852-10-25)Template:Safesubst:London, England, U.K. Died 26 April 1926(1926-04-26) (aged 72)Template:Safesubst:New York City, New York, U.S.A. Template:Safesubst:Resting place Template:Safesubst:Template:Safesubst:Occupation Stage Actress

date.headline: Shankar Jaikishan (Death)
date.text:
Shankar Jaikishan, also known as S/J, is an Indian music composer duo in the Hindi film industry, working together from 1949–1971. Shankar-Jaikishan, along with other artists, wrote "everlasting" and "immortal melodies" in fifties and sixties. Their best work was noted for being "raga-based and having both lilt and sonority".

Read more...
Take a look at DBpedia...
